review_title: The date here is still 1965 and red-tape, laziness and overall mismanagement reign supreme
pros: There are practically very few pros. Apart from a laid-back work environment and slow-moving pace of work. Decisions here could take years, so it gives you a lot of time to kick back and relax.
cons:
Way too many to list. However the following rank high on that long list:

1) The pay is marginally lower than what you would make in a similar position elsewhere.

2) The Bureaucracy of top management and the slow pace at which they make decisions

3) Most of the top management is technology illiterate and sometimes are technology averse.

4) This shows up in the way they handle basic processes such as student enrollment, payroll etc. Everything is still done on paper, as if it were 1965. 

5) Red-tape at all levels will prevent you from getting anything done. Even secretaries will attempt to slow down your progress if are not in their good graces and their managers turn a blind eye to this obstructionism.

job_title: Visiting Lecturer in Madison Park, NJ
pros: Wonderful resources and access to learned, supportive colleagues. 4-Star benefits package as par of an overall average compensation package. Fairleigh has the resources to attract a celebrity element for a yearly arts program. For example, the year I won a competitive post as a visiting professor of writing, Bruce Springsteen came to the main Madison Campus and performed in an intimate setting with National Poet Laureate Robert Pinsky. Their conversation was moderated by the British singer/songwriter John Wesley Harding (who is also the writer Stace). The other faculty are amazing. Great setting as well.
cons: Expensive Tuition does not lead necessarily to a well-paid faculty. In short, faculty members are woefully underpaid. The University is notorious, statewide, for paying adjuncts the lowest rate of ANY college (this includes community colleges) and yet FDU has these minimum-wage adjuncts teaching key classes to undergraduates every single semester. As a side note: as a university that wants to be a world-class artistic hub, it is an absolute shame that the library has no film element to speak of.

pros: Benefits are great, with tons of time off. 4 day work weeks during the summer, 20 vacation days plus sick & personal paid time off. 401k is matched up to 8% after 2 yrs of employment.  A lot of very dedicated faculty give extra meaning to the job.
cons: Upper management is totally clueless as to how a modern business runs. Paper forms are the primary way of communications between departments. Excel is treated like high technology. For example, purchase orders are done with carbon-copy typewriters. Getting accurate official reports is close to impossible.

review_title: Some good experiences with the university community at times.
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Madison, NJ
pros: Great tuition benefits for self, spouse and dependents if they wish to study at a so-so university. Use of the fitness center and library is beneficial. Aiding students and others in need of service may be a good job duty.  When the university is closed, the work load is less.
cons: For public safety officers, it is a boring position opening and closing university buildings.  Most shifts require sitting in a security guard booth.  There are ten hours shifts.  And working a midnight shift is harmful to an employees' health.  Shift workers lose sleep and have loss of time with family.  it is a cat and mouse game all school year chasing underage students drinking alcohol and at times using illegal drugs.  Vandalism and auto accident reports are common offenses at the university.

job_title: Athletic Staff and Faculty in Port Murray, NJ
pros: Outstanding work/life balance. Most departments allow for very flexible hours. Strong 403b contribution from school.
cons: Pay...FDU pays its full time employees and staff BELOW the national average in most positions: faculty, staff, support staff, etc. When coupled with the fact that FDU is in extremely affluent area, it is difficult to recruit and maintain top people. Many leave quickly once they secure better pay in less hectic regions with lower costs of living. It is very difficult to have a family and work within an hour commute of Madison, NJ - unless spouse also has high paying job.

pros: It is a foot in the door to an academic career.
cons:
Too many long hours for which you are not paid.  All of the extra work is carefully phrased as a request, yet the expectation is that it is not a request at all.  Contract employees, such as adjuncts are not fired, but they are simply not re-hired if they do not perform all of the extra work "requested".  The University has one of the lowest pay rates for adjuncts in the country, and piles on too much extra work to allow the adjuncts to be effective teachers.  

Many adjunct professors must work several other jobs to make ends meet.  The University does not offer any benefits and expects extra work that is not detailed in the contract.

pros: Freedom to customize lesson plans, easy going staff and faculty. Classes are capped at 25 students (for standard upper division courses), and you have freedom to overload to 35.
cons: The building is very old and run down. The rooms are always really hot, the projectors are lucky if they work, and there are no computers in rooms (in most departments), so you must bring your own. The school will spend millions to tear out plants and plant new ones, but not to fix the broken toilets, projectors, or printers.

pros: beautiful grounds, friendly people to work with. Atmosphere of things changing for the better: enrollments up, buildings being updated, new programs offered. Admin at top committed to raising school's profile. The two non-US campuses offer great opportunities.
cons: Lower pay than surrounding schools. Some tenured faculty bitter and can't get them to pitch in so tenure track faculty have to pick up the slack. Too much fighting between departments. No incentive for regular faculty to teach in summer so courses aren't offered

review_title: Sufficient for a job, but for a career, look elsewhere.
pros: Pleasant campus atmosphere for the most part, many quality faculty members.
cons: Older buildings make for shoddy working conditions on many occasions (lack of heat, mold, etc.), a definite lack of respect from senior members of faculty/administration to employees in the trenches, nepotism reigns in some areas on campus.

review_title: My years at FDU-Florham were the best of my career!
job_title: Mid-level Administrator in Florham Park, NJ
pros: FDU allows an innovative, inspired and creative staff member to take the reins and fly! As a private university, staffing is lean; the positive side to that is that you can learn so many skills in your job, because it's less about the job description and more about where you want to take it! I developed skills and competencies at FDU-Florham that I have taken with me to other positions in ways I would never have been able to do had I worked somewhere else. In addition, the colleagues I met became family members to me. So many wonderful and dedicated professors, administrators, staff and maintenance crew. From the president to public safety officers, you're made to feel like you're part of a community. And the benefits are truly fantastic. Generous time off (Summer Fridays make the work week 28 hours; 2 days off at Spring Break!), the most liberal tuition remission policy in higher education, tons of campus perks and events, and a true concern for work-life balance.
cons: You won't get rich working at FDU. Salaries are below average, but they do whatever they can to give you perks in other ways. For example, in years where raises weren't given, they gave a bonus to everyone. When healthcare payouts are lower than expected in a given year, the university returns part of the premium to the employees. In my opinion, people spend too much time focusing on salary. If you don't like the salary, don't take the job. People who complain about money are often complaining about something else and using money as the excuse. FDU has a responsibility to be clear about the salary it can offer. It does that. Nuff said.

pros:

cons: No merit pay increases, few to no advancement opportunities, low tech out dated office equipment and procedures, entrenched management that resist changing to meet present day realities. Employee healthcare contribution increases every year without salary increases.

review_title: Okay place to work, used to be better.
